awd_titl_txt: RUI: Interaction of Polerovirus P0 Protein and Host Defense Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration: In their evolutionary battle with viruses, plants have developed mechanisms to prevent infection, while viruses have countered by evolving proteins that can overcome these plant defenses. This project will examine how one of these virus proteins from the Poleroviruses, designated P0, interacts with the plant Nicotiana glutinosa, a relative of tobacco. P0 overcomes RNA interference (RNAi), a plant defense mechanism that acts against viruses with RNA genomes, like the Poleroviruses, by eliminating a key RNAi enzyme, Argonaute 1 (AGO1). Nicotiana glutinosa has evolved a resistance (R) protein that causes infected cells to die when it encounters P0 from some Poleroviruses, preventing spread of the virus infection within the plant. The investigators will seek to discover the gene for this R protein using transposon tagging, a method that locates a gene by disrupting it through insertion of a foreign piece of DNA called a transposon.  The project will also investigate how P0 functions by creating mutants to determine protein regions crucial for activity, and by purifying P0 for structural analysis. This research will establish a new model system that could provide insight applicable to R protein function against the broad spectrum of pathogens and parasites that challenge modern agriculture, while providing opportunities for master's and undergraduate students to engage in molecular biology research. Undergraduate students conducting research on this project will be recruited from California State University, Fullerton, one of the nation's leading institutions for graduating Hispanic students with bachelor's degrees. Beyond serving the goals of integrating science and education for undergraduate and graduate students at California State University, Fullerton, this project will have broader impacts through the engagement of local high school students in summer research experiences that will enhance their science education and promote the pursuit of careers in science.

por.por_cntn:
Scientific Outcomes

Plants and the pathogens that infect them, which include viruses, are in a constant evolutionary struggle for survival. Plants have defenses that can make them immune to infection, while viruses evolve proteins to break through this line of defense. This project studied one such protein from a genus of viruses called Poleroviruses that are carried by aphids and infect a wide range of plants, including important crop species. Our work focused on the Polerovirus protein P0, which was previously shown to be important for overcoming a plant antiviral defense mechanism called RNA interference (RNAi) by causing the elimination of a plant protein named Argonaute 1 (AGO1). This research established a new model system in our lab to study plant immunity in the plant Nicotiana glutinosa, in which we found immunity to two different Poleroviruses, Turnip yellows virus and Potato leafroll virus. This immunity was accompanied by cell death in certain combinations of N. glutinosa plant lines and different Poleroviruses. To gain an understanding of how N. glutinosa can have such a broad recognition of different P0 proteins and different outcomes (with or without cell death), we undertook a detailed deletion and mutation analysis of the P0 protein from Turnip yellows virus (P0Tu) and performed parallel deletion analyses of P0 from Potato leafroll virus (P0PL) and Cucurbit aphid-borne yellows virus (P0CA). This work identified regions of the P0 proteins that are essential for its function in causing AGO1 elimination and in inducing resistance responses. This N. glutinosa immunity to different Poleroviruses suggests the existence of a broad spectrum immunity that might be long-lasting in the field. Understanding how this immunity works could be important for future development of crops that can maintain long-term resistance to rapidly evolving pathogens.

Broader Impact Outcomes

This project introduced twenty undergraduate students and five master’s students to research in a laboratory at California State University, Fullerton, one of the nation's leading institutions for graduating Hispanic students with bachelor's degrees. Many students who have graduated already have gone on to pursue higher degrees or jobs in biotechnology. The PI has additionally integrated aspects of this research into the laboratory of the course Plant Molecular Biology (BIOL448) at the PI’s institution to extend exposure of undergraduate students to this NSF-funded project. Beyond serving the goals of integrating science and education for undergraduate and graduate students at California State University, Fullerton, this project had broader impacts through the engagement of local high school students, high school teachers and community college students in a Weekend Research Experience at California State University, Fullerton (supported by the Howard Hughes Medical Institute) aiming to enhance their science education and promote the pursuit of careers in science.
